title: Ibrox Park (1887–1899)
text:
Ibrox Park was a <a href="association%20football">football</a> ground in <a href="Ibrox%2C%20Glasgow">Ibrox</a>, Scotland. It was the home ground of <a href="Rangers%20F.C.">Rangers</a> from 1887 until they moved to the adjacent <a href="Ibrox%20Stadium">second Ibrox</a> in 1899. The ground staged the <a href="Scottish%20Cup%20Final">Scottish Cup Final</a> four times and also three <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a> international matches.
History.
Rangers' previous ground at <a href="Kinning%20Park%20%28sports%20ground%29">Kinning Park</a> had been built up to hold 20,000 people, but further expansion was impossible and so the club identified a site further west to build a new ground. Although the site at <a href="Ibrox%2C%20Glasgow">Ibrox</a> (at that time part of the <a href="burgh">burgh</a> of <a href="Govan">Govan</a>, today part of <a href="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>) was then on the outskirts of the city, it had good transport links, including the nearby <a href="Ibrox%20railway%20station">Ibrox railway station</a>. A ten-year lease on the site was secured and a ground constructed by Fred Braby & Co. An uncovered 1,200-seat stand was erected on the northern side of the pitch with an adjacent pavilion. The other three sides were terraced, with a running track around the pitch. The ground was opened on 20 August 1887 with a friendly match against <a href="Preston%20North%20End%20F.C.">Preston North End</a>.
A new grandstand was built on the southern side of the pitch, after which the ground was used to host three <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a> internationals; an <a href="1889%20British%20Home%20Championship">1889 British Home Championship</a> match against <a href="Ireland%20national%20football%20team%20%281882%E2%80%931950%29">Ireland</a> (7–0 to Scotland), an <a href="1892%20British%20Home%20Championship">1892 British Home Championship</a> match against <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a> (1–4) and an <a href="1897%20British%20Home%20Championship">1897 British Home Championship</a> match against Ireland (5–1). It was also used to host the <a href="1889%E2%80%9390%20Scottish%20Cup">1890 Scottish Cup final</a>, and the replay, between <a href="Queen%27s%20Park%20F.C.">Queen's Park</a> and <a href="Vale%20of%20Leven%20F.C.">Vale of Leven</a>.
Rangers were playing at the ground when they joined the new <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League">Scottish Football League</a> for the <a href="1890%E2%80%9391%20Scottish%20Football%20League">1890–91 season</a>, with the first league match played at the ground on 18 August 1890, a 5–2 win against <a href="Heart%20of%20Midlothian%20F.C.">Hearts</a> in front of a crowd of 4,000. The ground was chosen to host the <a href="1892%20Scottish%20Cup%20Final">1892 Scottish Cup Final</a> between <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a> and Queen's Park, but proved inadequate for the estimated 30,000 attendance. There were further problems when Ibrox hosted the international against England three weeks later; a stand collapsed, causing two deaths. The <a href="1893%20Scottish%20Cup%20Final">1893 Cup Final</a>, again between Celtic and Queen's Park, was also staged at Ibrox, but again there were problems; the match was declared void due to poor pitch conditions and had to be played again. The ground hosted the Cup Final for the fourth and last time when <a href="St%20Bernard%27s%20F.C.">St Bernard's</a> played <a href="Renton%20F.C.">Renton</a> in <a href="1895%20Scottish%20Cup%20Final">1895</a>.
With the new <a href="Celtic%20Park">Celtic Park</a>, opened in 1892, becoming established as Glasgow's leading football venue, Rangers subsequently decided to take out a lease on a new site adjacent to Ibrox Park and build a new stadium from scratch, which opened in December 1899. The second Ibrox Park (now <a href="Ibrox%20Stadium">Ibrox Stadium</a>) was built west of and partially overlapping the site of its predecessor, which backed directly onto Copland Road; the eastern end of the site was used for housing. The club's final league match at the original Ibrox Park was played on 9 December 1899, a 6–1 win over <a href="Kilmarnock%20F.C.">Kilmarnock</a> with 5,000 in attendance. However, the new Ibrox was not ready in time for the next match against <a href="St%20Mirren%20F.C.">St Mirren</a> on 16 December, which was instead played at <a href="Partick%20Thistle%20F.C.">Partick Thistle</a>'s <a href="Meadowside">Meadowside</a>.
